H0.text: Extreme thirst and weight loss are the two symptoms most likely associated with Type 1 diabetes, a condition in which the immune system attacks insulin‑producing pancreatic cells, leaving patients unable to regulate blood glucose levels.

H1.text: Intense aches and spasms are the two symptoms most likely associated with Type 1 diabetes, in which the immune system attacks the pancreatic cells that produce insulin, leaving people unable to regulate blood glucose levels.

H2.text: Severe loss of hearing and vision are the two symptoms most likely associated with Type 1 diabetes, a condition in which the immune system attacks insulin‑producing pancreatic cells, leading to impaired regulation of blood glucose levels.

H3.text: Excessive loss of coordination and memory are the two symptoms most likely associated with Type 1 diabetes, in which the immune system attacks the pancreatic cells that produce insulin, leading to an inability to regulate blood glucose levels.

A4.text: Common symptoms include frequent urination, increased thirst, increased hunger, weight loss, and other complications.

A5.text: The most pressing complications of type 1 diabetes are the always-present risks of poor blood sugar control: severe hypoglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis.
